Overhead was a beautiful sloping canopy made of white lapis lazuli, with a flawless, immeasurable luster, supported by tall poles of blue lapis lazuli, adorned with all kinds of arrays of rare jewels, held by hundreds of thousands of people surrounding the vehicle, singing and playing music, scattering flowers and burning incense. The eight-lane road was level and free of gravel, set on a bed of all precious substances, spread with gold sand, decorated with flowers of various jewels, lined on both sides with rows of jewel trees and railings of various gems. Above, it was covered with nets of golden bells, adorned with canopies of various jewels, and arrayed with many thousands of jeweled banners, pennants, and streamers. Rows of jewel buildings were arrayed on either side.

rin po che stegs bu la la la ni/ slong mo pa'i tshogs la yongs su bstab pa'i don du rin po che'i snod sna tshogs rin po che sna tshogs kyis yongs su bkang ba bkod; stegs bu la la la ni/ rgyan 'dod pa'i slong mo pa rnams brgyan pa'i don du rin po che thams cad kyi rgyan gyi rnam pa yongs su bkod/ stegs bu la la la ni/ sems can thams cad kyi bsam pa yongs su rdzogs par bya ba'i phyir yid bzhin gyi nor bu rin po che bkod/ stegs bu la la la ni/ su ci 'dod pa de dag la de sbyin pa'i don du kha zas dang / btung ba dang / bro ba sna tshogs kyis yongs su bkang ba'i snod mang po bkod/ stegs bu la la la ni/ rnam pa thams cad du mchog tu zhim pa'i ro dang / kha dag dang / dri dang / bro ba dang / reg bya yid du 'ong ba dang ldan pa'i lha rdzas kyi kha zas kyi rnam pa bkod/ stegs bu la la la ni/ ro bro ba sna tshogs dang ldan pa'i lha rdzas kyi shing thog sna tshogs thams cad spungs/ stegs bu la la la ni/ gos 'dod pa rnams yid bzhin du spyod du gzud pa'i phyir lha rdzas kyi gos rin po che kha dog sna tshogs dang ldan pa/ mdog bzang po rnam pa sna tshogs dag dang / ri mo sna tshogs shin tu spa bar rnam par phye ba/ shin tu btsun pa la 'os pa/ shin tu phra ba/ rab tu 'jam pa/ thags su ma btags pa bye ba brgya phrag stong snyed yongs su bkod par gyur to/ /stegs bu la la la ni/ byug pa 'dod pa'i sems can rnams bsam pa ji lta ba bzhin du yongs su spyod du gzud pa'i phyir lha rdzas kyi spos kyi rnam pa kha dog dang / dri rnam pa sna tshogs thams cad dang ldan pa dag bkod par gyur to/ /stegs bu la la la ni/ sems can rnams bsam pa ji lta ba bzhin du yongs su spyod du gzud pa'i phyir yo byad thams cad kyi phung po dag bkod par gyur to/ /stegs bu la la la ni/ na chung gzugs bzang ba/ rab tu mdzes pa/ shin tu sdug pa/ cha lug sdug gu sna tshogs dang ldan pa/ yid du 'ong ba'i gos sna tshogs dang ldan pa/ yid du 'ong ba'i gos sna tshogs gyon pa rgyan thams cad kyis mdzes par brgyan pa/ byug pa sna tshogs kyis tshul sdug gur brgyan cing mdzes par byas pa'i lus dang ldan pa/ bud med kyi bzo dang / sgyu dang / shes nyen gyi tshul la mkhas pa dag bkod par gyur to/ /

“In some of those buildings were precious vessels filled with various jewels, to be given to those in need. In some buildings were all kinds of precious ornaments, for those in need of ornaments. In some buildings were wish-fulfilling jewels, to fulfill the wishes of all beings. In some buildings were vessels filled with all kinds of food and drink, to be given to whoever needed them. In some buildings were celestial foods of all the most pleasant appearances, fragrances, savors, and textures. In some buildings were various delicious celestial fruits. In some buildings were millions of fine celestial garments, for those in need of clothing to use as they wished. In some buildings were all kinds of the finest celestial fragrances, for those who wanted perfume, to use at will. In some buildings were all kinds of utensils for people to use as they wished.

de'i tshe rgyal po'i gnas sdong po ri bo'i dpal de nyid na sbrul tshong ma'i dam pa rgyal po'i longs spyod du 'os pa/ blta na mdzes pa zhes bya ba zhig yod pa de'i bu mo dga' ba'i 'od kyi dpal shin tu sbyangs pa zhes bya ba gzugs bzang ba/ shin tu mdzes pa/ blta na sdug pa/ ha cang yang mi ring / ha cang yang mi thung / ha cang yang mi sbom/ ha cang yang mi phra/ ha cang yang mi dkar/ ha cang yang mi sngo ba/ skra mthon mthing du 'dug pa/ mig dkar nag 'byes pa/ bzhin yid du 'ong pa/ tshangs pa'i dbyangs dang ldan pa/ 'jam zhing snyan par smra ba/ shes rab dang ldan pa/ shes nyen gyi tshul thams cad la mkhas pa/ gtsug lag thams cad la shes pa/ brtson pa/ le lo med pa/ rim gro yod pa/ mos pa dang ldan pa/ byams pa'i sems bdog pa/ khong khro ba mi mnga' ba/ blta na mi ngoms shing yid du 'ong ba/ 'dod chags dang / zhe sdang dang / gti mug chung ba/ ngo tsha shes shing khrel yod pa/ drang zhing mnyen pa/ g.yo dang sgyu med pa zhig yod de/ de ma dang lhan cig tu bu mo du ma zhig gis bskor te rin po che'i shing rta la zhon nas rgyal po'i gnas sdong po ri bo'i dpal nas byung ste rgyal pos bka' stsal nas rgyal bu gzhon nu gzi brjid kyi bdag po'i mdun nas phar rgyal bu gzhon nu de la glu len cing 'dong 'dong ba las/ rgyal bu gzhon nu gzi brjid kyi bdag po mthong nas 'dod chags kyi sems shin tu mi bzad pa zhig g.yos te/ rgyal bu gzhon nu gzi brjid kyi bdag po shin tu yid du 'ong ches nas rjes su 'brang zhing sems la rang dbang med pas/ blta na sdug pa la 'di skad ces smras so/ /ma 'di ltar mkhyen par mdzod cig /gal te bdag rgyal bu gzhon nu gzi brjid kyi bdag po la ma btang na ni/ 'gum pa'am/ srog la 'bab pa'i sdug bsngal gcig tu 'gyur ro/ /des smras pa/ bu mo/ de lta bu'i sems ma skyed cig/ gzhon nu 'di ni/ 'khor los bsgyur ba'i mtshan dang ldan pa ste/ de'i yab nor gyi bdag po mi bzhugs par 'gyur na/ 'khor los bsgyur ba'i rgyal srid la gnas par 'gyur ba'i gnas yod de/ de 'khor los bsgyur ba'i rgyal por 'gyur bas de'i bud med rin po che nam mkha' la 'gro ba 'byung bar 'gyur la/ bu mo bdag cag kyang sbrul tshong ma dag cig ste/ 'jig rten thams cad dga' bar byed pa yin gyi/ yu bus sems can 'ga' zhig la nam 'tsho'i bar du bsnyen bkur mi byar mi rung ba'ang med de/ yu bu ni; rgyal po nor gyi bdag po'i bkas rgyal bu gzhon nu gzi brjid kyi bdag po'i rim gror 'dong 'dong bar zad kyi/ de lta bu'i sems brtan par ma byed cig /gnas de ni/ thob par yang shin tu dka'o/ /

“At that time there was a courtesan named Beautiful in that metropolis, with whom the king consorted. She had a lovely daughter named Splendor of Delight in Virtuous Conduct, who was neither too tall nor too short, neither too stout nor too lean, neither too heavy nor too light. She had black hair and eyes, a pleasant face, and a clear voice. She spoke sweetly and kindly, she was wise, versed in all arts and sciences, clever and diligent, dignified and serene, kind-hearted and gentle, always pleasant to be with. She had scarcely any desire, aversion, or folly; she was modest and conscientious, soft and sincere, free from guile and deceit, self-controlled. She and her mother, accompanied by many girls, got in a jeweled chariot and rode out of the city before the prince Lord of Glory. Looking for the prince, going according to the king’s directions, when she saw the prince she became greatly enamored of him. Bound by the excessive affection she conceived for the prince, unable to control herself, she said to her mother, ‘If you do not give me to the prince Lord of Glory, I will die or suffer torment equal to death.’ Her mother said, ‘Do not think this way. This prince has the marks of a supreme ruler, and it is obvious that after his father passes away he will succeed to the throne and become king. At that time a special woman will appear from the sky. Furthermore, we prostitutes give pleasure to everyone; we do not serve one person all our lives as a rule. We have set out to attend the prince Lord of Glory at the command of the king Lord of Wealth. Do not hold fast to this wish of yours, for it is unattainable.’

de'i tshe de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas sku nyi ma dam pa zhes bya ba mkhyen pa dang zhabs su ldan pa/ bde bar gshegs pa; 'jig rten mkhyen pa/ bla na med pa/ skyes bu 'dul ba'i kha lo sgyur ba/ lha dang mi rnams kyi ston pa sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das 'jig rten du byung ste/ de'i snying po byang chub chos kyi sprin shin tu sdug pa'i 'od ces bya ba yang bza' shing gi ra ba spos kyi myu gu'i rtse mo las 'od kyi sprin 'byung ba zhes bya ba de'i nang du byung ste/ der bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa sku nyi ma dam pa thog ma mngon par rdzogs par sangs rgyas nas zhag bdun lon pa
de bu mo shing rta la zhon bzhin du yur zhing 'chog 'chog pa'i rmi lam du mthong nas sad par gyur pa dang sngon gnyen bshes su gyur pa'i lha mo zhig gis bstan pa/ bu mo/ de bzhin gshegs pa sku nyi ma dam pa de snying po byang chub chos kyi sprin shin tu sdug pa'i 'od ces bya ba rnam par spyod cing thog ma mngon par rdzogs par sangs rgyas nas zhag bdun lon te byang chub sems dpa'i tshogs kyis yongs su bskor cing / lha dang / klu dang / gnod sbyin dang / dri za dang / lha ma yin dang / nam mkha' lding dang / mi'am ci dang / lto 'phye chen po dang / tshangs pa dang / gya nom snang ba dang / 'og min gyi lha'i tshogs kyis mdun du byas shing bzhugs te/ der sa'i lha mo thams cad kyang kun nas 'dus/ chu'i lha mo dang / me'i lha mo dang / rlung gi lha mo dang / rgya mtsho'i lha mo dang / chu'i klung gi lha mo dang / ri'i lha mo dang / mtshan mo'i lha mo dang / skya rengs 'char ba'i lha mo dang / nags tshal gyi lha mo dang / shing gi lha mo dang / sman gyi lha mo dang / lo tog gi lha mo dang / grong khyer gyi lha mo dang / rkang gis 'gro ba'i lha mo dang / snying po byang chub kyi lha mo dang / lus kyi 'od zer gyi lha mo dang / sems can gyi ris kyi lha mo dang / nam mkha'i lha mo dang / phyogs thams cad kyi lha mo dag kyang bcom ldan 'das sku nyi ma dam pa'i zhal blta ba'i phyir kun nas 'dus so/ /zhes nas

“Now, at that time a buddha named Supreme Sun was appearing in the world, a saint, perfectly enlightened, complete in knowledge and conduct, gone to felicity, supreme knower of the world, tamer of humans, teacher of celestials and humans, awake, blessed. He was at an enlightenment site called Light Emerging from the Cloud of Teaching in the park Cloud of Light on a Mountain of Fragrant Plants, where he enjoyed his first seven days since attaining enlightenment.
“The girl, who was reclining in the chariot, saw that buddha in a dream. When she awoke, a goddess who had been a relative in a past life told her that the buddha was in the park, in his first week of enlightenment, surrounded by a group of enlightening beings, before a crowd of all kinds of spirits, and that all the deities of earth, space, water, fire, wind, oceans, rivers, mountains, night, dawn, forests, trees, plants, grain, cities, foot tracks, sanctuaries, bodies of light, habitations, the sky, and all directions had gathered to see the buddha Supreme Sun.

de ltar des de bzhin gshegs pa mthong ba dang de bzhin gshegs pa'i yon tan thos pas bag tsha med pa thob par gyur te skabs su bab nas rgyal bu gzhon nu gzi brjid kyi bdag po'i mdun du de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag smras so/ /
“Emboldened by seeing the buddha and hearing of the buddha’s virtues, finding a favorable opportunity, the girl then spoke these verses before the prince:

gzugs kyi mchog gis 'jig rten khyad par 'phags/ / yon tan rnams kyis thams cad phyogs su grags/ / shes rab stobs kyi bdag dang 'dra ma mchis/ / sgyu rtsal dga' ba sgyu ma'i tshul kun 'tshal/ /
srog chags mang po stong 'phrag du ma yis/ / 'dod chags dbang gis bdag la rab bltas kyang / / gzhon nu bdag ni 'jig rten gang la yang / / glo ba chags par gyur pa gcig ma mchis/ /
sems can gang la'ang zhen par gyur pa'am/ / gang la'ang khong khror bdag gi sems ma gyur/ / gang la'ang dgra mi bgyid de zhe mi sdang / / bdag ni sems can sman par dga' ba lags/ /
sku gzhon sku mchog yon tan rab mnga' khyod/ / gang tshe bdag gis gsal bar mthong gyur pa/ / de tshe dbang po kun kyang nyams su bde/ / rgya che yangs par shin tu dga' bar gyur/ /
khyod kyi dbu bzang lcang lor 'khyil ba 'am/ / rin chen rnam snang mdog tu mthon mthing gsal/ / zhal gyi smin sdug 'phral ba shangs su mdzes/ / khyod kyi zhal sngar lus 'di bdag 'bul lo/ /
mtshan gyi rab 'chang gzi brjid che mnga' ba/ / sku gzugs gser gyi ri bo bzang po 'dra/ / khyod kyi spyan sngar bdag lta mi mdzes te/ / zil du rlog pas snag tsha'i gzugs kyang 'dra/ /
spyan gsal ring la dkar nag 'byes pas mdzes/ / shin tu zhal rgyas seng+ge'i za 'gram can/ / khyod kyi gsung ni thogs pa ma mchis na/ / gsung mchog mnga' bas bdag ni gzung du gsol/ /
khyod kyi zhal na ljags yangs mnga' ba ni/ / mdog dmar yangs pa rin chen mchog gi 'od/ / tshangs dbyangs yan lag mchog gi gsung mnga' bas/ / gsung zhing 'gro ba rab tu dga' ba mdzad/ /
khyod kyi zhal na thags bzang tshems mnga' ba/ / dung ltar dri med shin tu rnam par gsal/ / 'dzum zhing bzhad pa rnam par ston mdzad kyang / / skyes bu dpa' khyod 'gro ba dga' bar mdzad/ /
khyod kyi sku la mtshan rab mdzes pa rnams/ / sum cu rtsa gnyis dag cing 'od kyang gsal/ / sku gzugs bzang po yongs su des brgyan pas/ / mi yi dbang po 'khor los bsgyur ba byon; ;

I am known in the world for beauty, Renowned everywhere for virtues.
None compares to me in the power of knowledge; I know all arts, amusements, and magic.
Hundreds, thousands of men Look on me with lust, But I have no desire For people of the world.
I have no ill-will, Neither am I pleased by anyone.
I have neither anger nor hatred; I delight in the welfare of all.
When I saw you, young man, excellent In form and strength, endowed with virtue, All my senses were delighted, And immense joy arose in me.
Your complexion is like a pure shining jewel, Your hair is black and curly, You have a fine brow and nose; I offer myself to you.
You have excellent features.
Resplendent, you are like a mountain of gold.
In your presence I do not shine; I am like a pile of charcoal.
Your eyes are large and dark, Your jaw is like a lion’s, your face like the full moon.
The fine sound of your voice is irresistible; Please take me in.
Your tongue is long and broad, Coppery red, soft, shining like a jewel; With your superb, clear voice You delight people when you speak.
Your teeth are even, shining white, Clean and well spaced; When you show them as you smile, You delight people, O hero.
Your body has the thirty-two marks Of greatness, brilliantly shining, pure.
Adorned with them, you will become A sovereign ruler of men.
shin tu rgyas pa chen po'i mdo/ /sangs rgyas phal po che zhes bya ba las/ sdong pos brgyan pa'i le'u ste/ bam po brgya brgyad pa/

de nas rgyal bu gzhon nu gzi brjid kyi bdag pos bu mo dga' ba'i 'od kyi dpal shin tu sbyangs pa la 'di skad ces smras so/ /bu mo/ /khyod su'i/ khyod la yongs su srung ba ni/ gang zhig yod/ bu mo/ /nga la ni/ gzhan gyis yongs su bzung ba'i bud med bdag gir byar mi rung ngo/ /zhes nas de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag kyang smras so/ /
“Then the prince Lord of Glory said to the maid Splendor of Delight in Virtuous Conduct, ‘Whose daughter are you, whose ward? I cannot make another’s ward my own.’ Then he spoke these verses:

blta sdug gzugs kyi yon tan legs ldan pa/ / mtshan bzang bsod nams rnam par dag pa'i lus/ / khyod la dri ba'i don 'di nga la smros/ / lus mchog khyod ni su yis yongs su bzung / /
khyod la pha dang ma ni yod dam med/ / khyim thab med dam khyod ni su zhig dbang / / gzugs mdzes khyod la sems can gzhan nam gcig / bdag gi yin par 'du shes byed med dam/ /
khyod kyi yid ni gsod la mi dga' grang / / gzhan las ma byin 'phrog par mi byed dam/ / 'dod pas log par g.yem la mi dga' grang / / rdzun du brjod smrar yid ni mi smros sam/ /
khyod kyi blo gros mdza' dbyen mi 'jug gam/ / tshig brlang gzhan la gnod par mi smra grang / / gzhan gyi nor la chags par sems med dam/ / 'gro ba rnams la gnod par mi sems grang / /
lta ba'i 'brog dgon lam du ma zhugs grang / / las kyi rgyud la ye rngam sems med dam/ / g.yo mdog sgyu yi dbang du mi 'gro 'am/ / mi 'thad 'jig rten gnod par mi byed grang / /
pha ma gnyen dang mdza' bshes bla ma la; ; sri zhu rim gro bya ba'i tshul 'chang ngam/ / phongs par gyur pa yongs su bsdu don du/ / khyod kyi yid la sbyin pa'i sems yod dam/ /
chos dang mthun par dus su 'doms byed cing / / lus dang sems yid yongs su dag byed la/ / yang dag las su rung ba skyed byed pa'i/ / dge bshes rnams la dga' ba'i sems yod dam/ /
sangs rgyas rnams la rim gror byed ldan nam/ / sangs rgyas sras la dga' mchog yod dam med/ / gang las bde gshegs sras rnams skyer 'gyur ba'i/ / chos kyi dam pa de ni shes mi shes/ /
chos yid mchog la gnas par khyod byed grang / / chos min spyad pa'i blo gros med grang ngo/ / legs pa mtha' yas yon tan rgya mtsho la/ / gus pa'i sri zhu dga' sems mchog yod dam/ /
skye bo mgon med phongs par gyur pa yi/ / 'bren pa rnams la byams pa'i yid yod dam/ / ngan song 'gro ba'i lam la zhugs pa yi/ / shin tu nyam thag snying rjes sems grang ngo/ /
gzhan gyi phun sum tshogs pa mthong gyur na/ / khyod ni dga' ba mchog dang ldan 'gyur ram/ / skye bo nyon mongs rnams kyis 'khol gyur la/ / shes rab mthu bskyed btang snyoms byed mi byed/ /
mi shes gnyid log skye bo mang mthong na/ / byang chub dam par smon lam 'debs byed grang / / bskal pa mtha' yas spyad pa spyod pa na/ / smon lam dam pas skyo bar mi 'gyur grang / /

O lovely one, endowed with beauty of form, With fine features and a pure body, I ask you to tell me this— Whose ward are you?
Have you father or mother, Brother, husband, or master, Or someone else who thinks of you As his, treating you kindly?
I hope you are not vicious, Do not steal, Are not promiscuous, And do not lie.
I hope you do not cause discord, Do not slander others, Do not covet others’ goods, And are not hostile toward anyone.
May you not stand on the wasteland of views; Let your intelligence not be taken away by habits; May you not exert bad influence on people By guile or deceit.
Do you love and respect your parents, Relatives, friends, and elders? Does your heart reach out To give to the poor to help them?
Are you well disposed toward spiritual benefactors Who tell you about religion at the appropriate time? Are you truly healthy and capable In body and mind?
Do you respect the buddhas And love the enlightening beings? Do you know the supreme Teaching From which the enlightening beings are born?
Can you abide by the supreme religion And not do any wrong? Do you have higher love and respect For the infinite ocean of virtues?
Are you kind To the helpless and lost? Are you really compassionate Toward evildoers?
Are you most happy To see the success of others? Are you indifferent, by the power of wisdom, To those who annoy you for no reason?
Seeing people in the slumber of ignorance, Do you firmly seek supreme enlightenment? Would you not weary of endless ages Of spiritual practice?

de nas bu mo dga' ba'i 'od kyi dpal shin tu sbyangs pa'i ma sbrul tshod ma'i gtso mo blta na sdug pas/ rgyal bu gzhon nu gzi brjid kyi bdag po la 'di skad ces smras so/ /gzhon nu/ bdag gi bu mo 'di ni/ rdzus te byung ba pad+mo'i nang nas skyes pa ste/ sngon chad khyim gyi nang nas phyi rol tu ma byung ngo/ /zhes nas de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag kyang smras so/ /

“Then the supreme courtesan Beautiful, mother of the maid Splendor of Delight in Virtuous Conduct, said to the prince Lord of Glory, ‘This daughter of mine, who was spontaneously born from within a lotus, has never before gone out of the house.’ Then she spoke these verses:

bu mo 'di la khyod kyis gang smras pa; ; de ni bdag gis rim pas khyod la brjod/ / ji ltar bu mo 'di skyes bskyed bskyed pa/ / bdag gis khyod la gsol gyi gsan du gsol/ /
gang tshe dgung sangs khyod ni bltams gyur pa/ / de tshe bdag gi bu mo 'di skyes te/ / rdzus te dri med pad+mo'i sbubs nas byung / / yan lag kun tshang mig yangs 'di yang skyes/ /
dus kyi nang na sos ka dus mchog la/ / sman dang lo tog myu gu thon pa'i tshe/ / sA la'i ra ba bza' shing rab mchog tu/ / bdag ni rtse dga' de khrod mchi mchi ste/ /
sna tshogs yal ga'i lo ma rgyas gyur cing / / zhugs shing me tog sdug rgyas sprin gyi mdog / bya bran sna tshogs sgra snyan zhugs shing nang / / nags khrod mya ngan ma mchis dgar mchis mchis/ /
rgyan dang ldan zhing shin tu yid 'ong la/ / rin chen rat+na sna tshogs 'tshal ba rnams/ / rol mo glu la shin tu bslab pa yi/ / bu mo brgya phrag brgyad dang bdag kyang ldan/ /
spos mchog ldan pa'i puN+Da rI ka dang / / rdzing 'gram me tog sil mas gtams pa yis/ / sa phyogs de na bud med mang po dang / / bdag cag de na dga' bar mchis mchis na/ /
chab dbus de nas rin chen pad+mo'i mchog / 'dab ma stong dang ldan pa byung bar gyur/ / lo ma rin chen yu ba bai DUr+ya/ / snying po 'dzam bu chu klung gser las bgyis/ /
spos mchog rin chen dam pa'i ze ba can/ / 'od chen dzam+bu'i rgyal mtshan kun tu 'phro/ / de tshe dgung la gdugs shig shar tam zhes/ / skye bo kun kyang yid gnyis 'tshal bar gyur/ /
dgung sangs rgyur nas pad+mo chen po de/ / gdugs kyi 'od kyis rab tu rgyas bgyis nas/ / snang ba de dang sgra snyan rab kyang bkye/ / 'di 'byung de ni sngon gyi ltas su byung / /
bud med rin chen 'di 'dra 'jig rten du/ / tshul khrims dam pa rnam par dag pas byung / / sug las bgyis pa chab 'tshal mi 'gyur bas/ / 'di ni sngon chad legs par spyad pa'i 'bras/ /
skra ni mthon mthing mig yangs ut+pa la/ / tshangs pa'i dbyangs ldan kha dog rnam dag ldan/ / phreng ba rgyan mchog cha lugs dbyibs su shis/ / dpal ltar dri med pad+mo'i mchog las skyes/ /
lus ni rnam dag yan lag rkyen du mnyam/ / lus kyi dbyibs legs yan lag yongs su tshang / / gser gyi gzugs la nor bus phyis pa 'dra/ / phyogs kun 'od kyis rnam par gda' bar gsal/ /
lus las tsan+dan rgyal po'i spos kyi dri/ / phyogs su rgyas par 'di yi lus las 'byung / / sgra snyan lha rdzas yid du 'ong brjod tshe/ / kha nas ut+pa la yi ngad kyang ldan/ /
'di ni gang tshe 'dzum zhing dgod pa'i tshe/ / rol mo'i sgra snyan de tshe 'byung bar 'gyur/ / bud med rin chen 'jig rten 'dir byung ste/ / tha ma la kun gyi dbang du 'gyur ma lags/ /
khyod ma gtogs par mi yi 'jig rten na/ / 'di yi bdag po gzhan ni gcig ma mchis/ / mtshan rab brgyan pa'i sku gzugs mdzes mnga' ba/ / khyod kyi zhal sngar bu mo 'di bzhes gsol/ /
'di ni ha cang mi ring mi thung ste/ / ha cang mi spo ma ha cang phra ma lags; ; lto ni gzhu 'dra nu ma shas kyang rgyas/ / yan lag skyon bral 'di ni khyod la 'os/ /
grangs dang yi ge shes bgyi tshul rnams dang / / lag brda'i tshul dang gtsug lag tshul la mkhas/ / 'jig rten kun na bzo rnams ji snyed pa/ / ma lus de la 'di ni pha rol phyin/ /
mda' gzhu'i tshul la'ang rnam pa brgyas su mkhas/ / 'phong gi cho ga rnam pa rangs par rtogs; ; dgra yid bzho zhing dbab pa kun la yang / / 'di ni mchog tu pha rol phyin par gyur/ /
lus rnams kun nas rin chen rnam dag pa'i/ / 'od mchog 'khor gyis shin tu mdzes pa ste/ / sngon gyi legs pas shin tu sdug par brgyan/ / 'di ni khyod kyi phyag rjed khyod la 'os/ /
mi yi 'jig rten gnas rnams ji snyed pa/ / de dag gso ba'i tshul gyi cho ga 'tshal; ; de dag ma lus thams cad zhir bgyi na'ang / / ma nor sman gyi cho gas gso la mkhas/ /
dzam+bu'i rgyal mtshan skad rnams thams cad dang / / skye bo'i nges tshig ma lus bye brag dang / / 'jig rten tha snyad brjod pa'i mtshams sbyar ba/ / sna tshogs kun la'ang 'di ni pha rol phyin/ /
dbyangs kyi yan lag mngon par sgrub pa'i tshul/ / de dag bye brag tshul la'ang rab tu zhugs/ / 'jig rten glu gar rnam pa ji snyed pa/ / ma lus de rnams kun gyi tshul yang 'tshal/ /
rol mo sil snyan dag gi thabs rnams dang / / bzhad gad rol mo'i tshul la rnam par mkhas; ; chags dang ma chags mi rnams mngon 'tshal kyang / / khong khro chags par 'gyur ba ma mchis so/ /
'jig rten bud med sgra rnams ji snyed pa/ / khyad par nang du de la ma lus 'tshal; ; bud med skye bo'i skyon du bgyi ba rnams/ / grangs med de dag 'di la gcig ma mchis/ /
thil gyis blta dang zur gyis blta ba dang / / yan lag bstabs dang yan lag rnams bstan dang / / shes nyen kun la mkhas pa'i mthar phyin te/ / khyod kyi dgongs pa yongs su rdzogs par bgyid/ /
'di ni phrag dog ser sna ma mchis te/ / 'dod pa zhe dug mi ldang sdig mi bgyid/ / bzod cing drang la mnyen zhing des pa ste/ / mi khro mi brlang shin tu mkhas pa lags/ /
ldang ba'i ngang tshul yid du'ong ba'i ngag / rtag tu bla ma'i thugs dang sbyor ba ste/ / sku nyams gar bde lta zhing sri zhu che/ / khyod kyi spyod mthun rjes su snyegs tshul dang mthun/ /
rgyas shing gtugs dang nad dang ldan pa dang / / phongs pa shin tu sdug bsngal gyur pa dang / / mig dang bral zhing mgon skyabs ma mchis la/ / 'di ni snying brtse rtag tu skyed pa lags/ /
'di ni rtag tu gzhan don sems la brtson/ / bdag la sman pa sems par bgyid ma mchis/ / 'jig rten kun la sman par dga' ba ste/ / rlabs chen sems kyi yon tan kun gyis brgyan/ /
mchis sam nyal lam mchi 'am 'greng yang rung / / smra'am mi smra 'dzum zhing dgod kyang rung / / rtag tu bag mchis dran pa shes bzhin te/ / 'di ni 'jig rten kun gyis rtag tu bsngags/ /
bsod nams ldan pas kun tu rnam par snang / / 'gro ba kun kyang rtag tu dga' ba ste/ / 'di la lta bas 'jig rten ngoms mi 'gyur/ / 'di ni gang la'ang chags par 'gyur ma mchis/ /
dge ba shes rnams la sri zhu 'di che ste/ / de dag mthong bar rtag par rab tu dga'/ / rjes su ci 'byung lta zhing skyon med tshul/ / sems bdag brtan pa ri rab ri dang 'dra/ /
'di ni bsod nams mchog gis rtag tu brgyan/ / mi mdza' dgrar len 'di la yong ma mchis/ / 'di yi shes 'dra bud med gcig ma mchis/ / rgyal sras khyod la 'di ni tshul dang mthun/ /

Listen to what I say, O prince, About my daughter, of whom you ask. I will tell you of her birth And how she grew up.
On the very same morn as your birth, My daughter too was born, Generated spontaneously in the calyx of an undefiled lotus, All her limbs complete, with nice big eyes.
In springtime, the best of seasons, When the crops and herbs are growing, In my beautiful grove of sal trees I utterly forgot myself.
The branches were blooming with most beautiful flowers, The fruiting trees were like dense clouds; Amid the trees with singing birds I roamed, joyful, free from care.
I was with eight hundred girls, Adorned with garlands of flowers, Wearing various precious cloths, Well versed in song and speech.
I sat on the bank of a pond Filled with lotuses of various scents; The area around, strewn with flowers, Was filled by those well-cultivated girls.
In the middle of the water appeared A supremely fine lotus with a thousand petals; Its stem was lapis lazuli, its petals were diamond, Its pericarp was pure gold.
It had a multitude of stamens of the finest fragrant jewels And had a brilliant golden sheen: The people were confused— How could the sun rise at night?
Then, the night ended, from the rising sun, Stimulating with its glow, There emanated light and sweet sounds, Foretelling the birth of this girl.
Then this precious girl appeared in the human world, Pure in the best of conduct. No deed is lost to the doer; she was the fruition Of good actions in the past.
With dark hair, lotus-blue eyes, A clear voice and golden complexion, Finely clad in garlands, she emerged From the lotus, resplendent as pure light.
Her limbs are bright, her body evenly balanced; Her limbs are complete, her body well proportioned: She shines like a golden statue adorned with jewels, Illumining all directions.
The finest fragrance of sandalwood wafts from her body, Filling the air around her; As she speaks, with celestial sweetness, A scent like blue lotus comes from her mouth.
Whenever she smiles, Heavenly music plays; This treasure of a woman should not be abandoned To the control of the vulgar.
In the world of men no one can be found Who is worthy to be her husband, except you, A resplendent figure with the marks of greatness— Therefore, please accept this girl.
For she is not short or too tall, Not stout or too thin; She is slender at the waist, full-breasted, Suitable for you, with an impeccable body.
She has perfect knowledge of calculation, Writing, symbology, and technical literature; She has mastered all the arts and crafts In the whole world.
She is expert in archery And always hits her mark; Pacifying opponents by her power of attraction, She is ultimately successful everywhere.
All her limbs are like pure jewels; She radiates an aura of light.
Adorned by the virtues she has accomplished, She is fit to be your companion.
She knows the cause of all illnesses That afflict living beings, And she is able to cure them By correct use of medicines.
She has mastered all the different languages Of the people on the continent And the variety of customary usages Of society everywhere.
She knows the articulation of sounds And the means of differentiation among them, And she is expert in all The songs and dances in the world.
She is not jealous or envious, She is not lustful or ill-tempered; She is taciturn, honest, and gentle, Free from anger and harshness, very intelligent.
She is diligent, well behaved, not argumentative, Always obedient to the worthy; She is respectful, seeking to do whatever is good. She will do as you ask.
She is always compassionate toward the elderly, Toward the sick and the poor, Toward the suffering, the blind, And toward the helpless.
She is always thinking of the welfare of others, And never thinks of benefit for herself; Seeking the welfare of the whole world, She is adorned with superior virtues of mind.
She is never careless, always mindful and aware, Whether standing, sitting, reclining, or walking, Whether silent or speaking; She is always remembered and honored.
This virtuous one shines in all ways, And is always loved by people; None would tire of looking at her, But she has no attachment to the world.
Respectful of spiritual friends, She wants always to see you; This far-seeing, uncorrupted lady has a pure mind, Stable as the polar mountain.
Ever-adorned with her own virtues, She has no enemies at all; She has no peer in knowledge. She is fit to be your bride, O prince.

de nas rgyal bu gzi brjid kyi bdag po bza' shing gi ra ba spos kyi myu gu'i rtse mo las 'od kyi sprin 'byung bar phyin te/ bu mo dga' ba'i 'od kyi dpal shin tu sbyangs pa'i ma sprul tshong ma'i gtso mo blta na sdug ba'i mdun du bu mo dga' ba'i 'od kyi dpal shin tu sbyangs pa la 'di skad ces smras so/ /bu mo/ nga ni/ bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu zhugs pa yin te/ de bas na/ ngas thams cad mkhyen pa'i tshogs ni/ tshad med pa zhig bsag par bya dgos/ bskal ba mtha' dang dbus med pa zhig tu byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa spyad de pha rol tu phyin pa thams cad ni/ yongs su rdzogs par bya dgos/ phyi ma'i mtha'i bskal ba'i mur thug par ni/ de bzhin gshegs pa rnams la mchod par bya dgos te/ sangs rgyas thams cad kyi bstan pa ni/ yongs su gzung bar bya/ sangs rgyas kyi zhing thams cad ni/ yongs su sbyang bar bya/ de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi rigs ni; mi gcad par bya/ sems can gyi rgyud thams cad ni/ yongs su smin par bya/ sems can thams cad kyi 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal ni/ rnam par bzlog par bya/ mtha' las rgal bar bde ba la ni/ sems can rab tu dgod par bya/ sems can thams cad kyi ye shes kyi mig ni/ yongs su dag par bya/ byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyis bsgrub pa la ni; brtson par bya/ byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyi mnyam pa nyid la ni/ gnas par bya/ byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyis ni/ yongs su bsgrub par bya/ sems can gyi khams thams cad ni/ yongs su sbyang bar bya/ sems can thams cad kyi phongs pa yongs su gcad pa'i phyir bdag gi nor thams cad ni/ gtang bar bya/ phyi ma'i mtha'i mur thug pa'i bskal par spyin pa'i pha rol tu phyin pa la spyod pa'i tshe kha zas dang btung ba'i spyin pas ni/ sems can yongs su tshim par bya/ yo byad kyi dngos po thams cad yongs su btang bas ni/ slong ba'i tshogs thams cad yongs su tshim par bya dgos te/ de ltar bdog pa thams cad yongs su gtong ba la nan tan nyams su len pa'i tshe phyi nang gi dngos po gang ci yang rung ste/ yongs su mi gtang ba de lta bu med pas de ltar ngas bu dang / bu mo dang / chung ma yang sbyin par bya dgos/ /mig dang / mgo dang / rkang lag dang / yan lag dang / nying lag thams cad kyang yongs su gtang dgos na/ de'i tshe khyod gzhan la byin na/ /nga'i sbyin pa'i bgegs su 'gyur ro/ /bu yid du 'ong ba yongs su btang na/ yid mi dga' bar 'gyur ro/ /lus dang sems kyi sdug bsngal yang mang po zhig nyams su myong bar 'gyur ro/ /nga la bdog pa thams cad yongs su btang bar byas na/ ser sna'i sems su 'gyur ro/ /nga'i yan lag dang / nying lag gtubs shing slong mo ba rnams la gtong ba'i tshe yid mi dga' bar yang 'gyur ro/ /nam zhig na ngas khyod bor te/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i bstan pa la rab tu 'byung bar 'gyur ba de lta bu'i dus kyang yod de/ de'i tshe'ang khyod yid mi dga' bar 'gyur ro/ /zhes nas rgyal bu gzi brjid bdag pos de'i tshe bu mo dga' ba'i 'od kyi dpal shin tu sbyangs pa la tshigs su bcad de smras pa/

“Then the prince, having entered the park, said to the maid in the presence of her mother, ‘I have set out for supreme perfect enlightenment, whereby I may gather the infinite stores of omniscience, cultivate the practice of enlightening beings for infinite eons and perfect all the transcendent ways, serve the buddhas for endless eons, uphold the teaching of all buddhas, purify all buddha-lands, perpetuate the lineages of all buddhas, develop all groups of sentient beings to maturity, stop the pains of the mundane whirl for all sentient beings, lead sentient beings to ultimate bliss, clarify the eye of knowledge in all sentient beings, strive for the attainments of all buddhas and enlightening beings, abide in the equanimity of all enlightening beings, accomplish all the stages of enlightening beings, purify all sentient beings, cultivate total giving to put an end to poverty for all sentient beings, practice transcendent giving for endless eons and satisfy all sentient beings with gifts of food and drink, and satisfy all beggars by giving away all goods. As I practice total relinquishment, everything internal and external is to be given away—I am to give away my sons, daughters, wife; I am to relinquish my eyes, head, hands and feet, all my limbs. You will hinder my giving, you will become unhappy at the relinquishment of beloved children, you will feel much physical and mental pain, you will resent my determination to give up everything. When I cut off my limbs to give them to beggars, you will be pained and grieved. And there will come a time when I leave you to go forth into the tutelage of a buddha; at that time you will be unhappy.’ Then the prince spoke these verses to the maid:

ngas ni 'gro kun snying rje rab bskyed de/ / yun ring mchog nas byang chub rab zhugs pas/ / yang dag byang chub tshogs chen rgya mtsho rnams/ / tshad med thams cad yongs su rdzogs bya dgos/ /
bskal pa rgya mtsho mtha' dang dbus med par/ / mkha' ltar tshad med smon lam rnam sbyang zhing / / de bzhin gshegs pa bzhugs pa'i sa yi rnams/ / bskal pa mtha' yas yongs su sbyang yang dgos/ /
rgyal ba dus gsum 'byung ba thams cad kyi/ / pha rol phyin pa'i lam la ngas bslab ste/ / ye shes bla na med pa'i tshul chen gyis/ / byang chub lam mchog rnam par sbyang yang dgos/ /
phyogs rnams kun gyi zhing rnams thams cad kyang / / kun nas nyon mongs rnam par sbyang bar bya/ / 'jig rten kun gyi mi khom thams cad dang / / ngan song kun kyang rnam par bzlog dgos so/ /
nyon mongs bsgribs shing gti mug mun 'thoms pa'i/ / sems can kun kyang ma lus rnam sbyang dgos/ / sna tshogs thabs kyis yongs su sbyangs byas te/ / thams cad mkhyen lam tshul la dgod kyang dgos/ /
chags med sa rnams kun kyang ngas sbyangs te/ / bskal ba rgya mtshor rgyal ba mchod par bya/ / 'gro ba ma lus kun la byams bskyed de/ / 'jig rten dag tu ma lus sbyin gtang dgos/ /
slong ba kun nas 'dus shing 'ongs mthong nas/ / thams cad gtang bar rtag tu brtson gyur na/ / de'i tshe khyod ni nga sems mi mthun te/ / zhum zhing dma' la 'jungs par mi 'gyur ram/ /
nga yi mgo 'dod 'ongs par ngas mthong ste/ / byang chub sems dpa'i spyad pa spyod gyur na/ / de tshe khyod ni sdug bsngal gdungs 'gyur gyi/ / 'di 'dra'i don thos rab tu brtan par gyis/ /
nga yi rkang lag gtubs pa mthong gyur na/ / khyod ni mi dga' de tshe slong ba la/ / bud med ngang gis tshig drag mi bzod smra/ / don 'di thos shing sems la yongs su soms/ /
phangs pa'i dngos dang de bzhin bu rnams dang / / khyod kyang slong ba'i tshogs la sbyin dgos kyi/ / don 'di thos te mi dga' med na lta/ / khyod dga' thams cad de bzhin bya la rag /

I am going to fulfill the immeasurable ocean Of provisions for perfect enlightenment; Therefore, with compassion for all, I have set forth forever for enlightenment.
For infinite eons, measureless as air, I will purify my vow; For endless eons I will perform the preparations Of the initial stage of the buddhas.
I will learn the paths of transcendence From the buddhas of past, present, and future And perfect the path of supreme enlightenment By the great means of unexcelled knowledge.
I will purify all Defiled lands everywhere; I will remove all difficulties And evil ways from all worlds.
I will purify all beings Who are wrapped up in afflictions, blind with delusion; Developing them by various means, I will bring them into the path of omniscience.
I will accomplish the unobstructed stages And serve the buddhas for myriad eons; Generating kindness toward the world, I will give all gifts.
As I am engaged in giving all To beggars who come, Do not become depressed Or sad or unsympathetic.
Seeing benefit for one who wants my head, A wise person would delight in lofty conduct; You would be tormented, So hear my purpose and become firm.
You would be grieved at my giving My severed hands and feet to beggars And speak bitterly, faint and distressed; So hear my purpose and think about it.
I will give away my prized possessions, Even my children, yet I want you; Hear my aim and if you do not despair, All shall be as you wish.

de skad ces smras pa dang / bu mo dga' ba'i 'od kyi dpal shin tu sbyangs pas rgyal bu gzi brjid kyi bdag po la 'di skad ces smras so/ / gzhon nu ji skad gsung ba de ltar bgyi'o/ / bdag ni/ khyod ci dgyes pa dang / ci bzhed par longs spyod pa dang / gang du dgyes par mchi ba dang / thams cad du yang slad nam las pas rjes su 'brang ba dang / rtag tu zham ring sleb pa dang / don thams cad la brtson pa dang / thugs dang mthun par spyad pa dang / med par nyams su blang ba dang / mi mthun pa ma mchis par nan tan du bgyi ba'i tshul la spyad par bgyi'o/ / zhes nas bu mo dga' ba'i 'od kyi dpal shin tu sbyangs pas rgyal po'i sras gzi brjid kyi bdag po la tshigs su bcad de smras pa/ bdag gi lus 'di sems can dmyal ba yi/ /

“The maid replied to the prince, ‘Let it be as you say. I will do as you wish. I am at your service and will accompany you wherever you want to go. I will always stay with you and be diligent in all tasks. I will behave as you wish. I will exert myself properly and act in harmony with you.” Then she spoke these verses to the prince:

zhugs kyis yongs gdungs zhu bar gyur kyang rung / / khyod spyod skal ba mnyam pa'i phyag rjed du/ / tshe rabs rgya mtshor bdag gis spro bar bgyi/ / tshe rabs mtha' yas skyes pa re re zhing / /
bdag gi lus ni shin tu gtubs gshags kyang / / brtan dam sems kyis rab tu spro bar bgyi/ / ngang dge khyod kyis bdag gis khyim thab mdzod/ / khor yug ri yis bskal ba mtha' yas su/ /
bdag gi mgo ni yongs su btags gyur kyang / / sems la mi bde ma mchis dad par bgyi/ / khyod kyis rtag par bdag gi khyim thab mdzod/ / khyod kyis tshe rabs grangs med thams cad du/ /
bdag la thugs brtan thugs kyis mnga' mdzad de/ / yan lag sha gtubs gzhan la stsal ba mdzod/ / khyod kyi chos la bdag kyang brtan gzhag gsol/ / bdag gi lus ni slad na ma las par/ /
skyes bu lha yi sras po khyod la dbul/ / bskal pa rgya mtshor spyod pa mdzad pa'i tshe/ / skye bo slong ba rnams la dgyes par stsol/ / sems can kun la thugs rje mtha' yas pa/ /
bskyed de sems can rgya mtsho bsdu slad du/ / byang chub dam pa mchog tu khyod zhugs pas/ / de slad bdag kyang thugs rjes bzung ba mdzod/ / longs spyod don dang nor gyi don ma lags/ /
'dod spyod dga' ba bskyed pa'i don slad du/ / sems can mchog khyod khyor 'tshal ma lags kyi/ / khyod dang spyod pa mthun par spyad slad du'o/ / spyan gsal mdzes shing byams pa'i thugs mnga' ba/ /
khyod ni 'jig rten gzigs pa ci tshul lags/ / thugs rje che yi 'dod chags thugs mi mnga'/ / de las thub dbang 'gyur ba gdon mi 'tshal; ; khyod kyi zhabs kyis bcags pa'i sa rnams kyang / /
dri med rin chen 'od du gnas pa las/ / khams gsum kun tu 'khor los bsgyur bar yang / / mtshan rab yongs kyis brgyan byon gdon mi 'tshal/ / bdag gis g.yar lam mthong ba dgung zhig la/ /
chos bzang sprin 'od byang chub snying po yi/ / shing dbang drung na de bzhin gshegs pa bzhugs/ / sangs rgyas sras mang du mas mdun du bdar/ / rgyal ba'i dbang po sku mchog nyi ma de/ /
dzam+bu chu klung rin chen 'tsher ba 'dra/ / g.yar lam mthong bar phyag gis bdag mgo byugs/ / de nas sad nas glo ba rab tu dga'/ / dga' ba'i 'od ces bgyi ba rnam dag lus/ /
sngon chad gnyen bshes gyur pa'i lha mo yis/ / bdag la bstan pa bde gshegs de nyid ni/ / snying po yang dag byang chub yongs la zhugs/ / sngon yang gzhon nu gzi brjid khyod blta zhes/ /
bdag gi sems bskyed de ltar bsam par gyur/ / mdang sum dgung la lha mo dge ba yis/ / gzhon nu de ni mthong bar 'gyur zhes bstan/ /
bdag gis bde gshegs g.yar lam rmis pas mthong / / yongs su dag pa'i sems can khyod kyang mthong / / yid bzhin bsam 'grub khyod dang bdag bcas pas/ / de ring rgyal ba de la mchod par bgyi/ /

Even if my body should be burnt to death In the fires of hell, I would endure it for myriad lifetimes As your companion in practice.
Even if life after life for endless lives My body were cut asunder, I would endure it with a steadfast mind If you were my husband.
Even if the mountains should crush My head for endless ages, I would endure it unfazed If you became my husband.
In infinite lifetimes you may cut off Your own limbs and give them to others; Lead me to control of my thoughts And make me firm in my duty.
I give you my body completely, O prince of men; Performing spiritual practice for myriad ages, Give me to whoever wants me, and I will be happy.
You have set out for supreme enlightenment, With infinite compassion for beings; Having taken all beings into your care, Take me in too with compassion.
It is not for enjoyment Or wealth or sensual pleasure That I want you, best of men, for my husband, But to share the same spiritual practice.
You look upon all beings With clear eyes and kind heart; Being compassionate with undefiled mind, You will surely become a king of sages.
As you walk along, a jewellike glow From your footsteps remains on the earth, pure; Endowed with the marks of greatness, You will surely become a sovereign king in the human world.
In a dream I saw the enlightenment site Illumined by clouds of true teaching in this kingdom; With the buddha sitting at the foot of the best of trees, In the company of many enlightening beings.
That exalted buddha Supreme Sun Is like a mountain of finest rose gold; In my dream he patted my head, And I awoke then, full of joy.
A pure-bodied goddess named Light of Delight, Who had been a companion in the past, Told me the buddha was here, Staying at the supreme site of enlightenment.
I had been thinking before that I wanted To see the prince Lord of Glory, And I was told by the goddess I would see the prince soon.
Now I have seen the buddha in a dream, And have seen you, the perfect man; My wish is fulfilled, and I am happy; With you now I will honor that supreme sage.

de nas rgyal po'i bu gzi brjid kyi bdag pos de bzhin gshegs pa sku nyi ma dam pa'i mtshan thos te/ sangs rgyas blta ba'i skabs byung nas dga' ba dang mos pa'i shugs chen po skyes te bu mo dga' ba'i 'od kyi dpal shin tu sbyangs pa la nor bu rin po che lnga brgyas mngon par gtor nas gtsug gi rin po che dpal gyi 'od 'bar ba zhes bya ba'ang de la byin no/ /me'i mdog ltar 'dug pa'i nor bu rin po che dam pas brgyan pa'i gos rin po ches kyang de bkab bo/ /de de ltar rim gro byas kyang dga' bar gyur pa'am/ nyams bde bar gyur pa lta bu'ang med la/ dga' ba dang mos par ma gyur gyi/ gzhan du na thal mo sbyar cing mig mi 'gebs par gzhon nu gzi brjid bdag gi gdong la lta zhing gnas par gyur to/ /

“Then the prince, having heard the name of the buddha Supreme Sun and having thus gotten the opportunity to see the buddha, became very joyful; he showered the maid Splendor of Delight in Virtuous Conduct with five hundred jewels, gave her a shining crown of jewels, and covered her with a precious robe the color of fire blazing with jewels. And she, thus honored, neither rejoiced nor wept, nor did anything but gaze steadily at the prince with palms joined in respect.
de nas sprul tshong ma'i gtso mo blta na sdug pas rgyal bu gzhon nu gzi brjid kyi bdag po la tshigs su bcad de smras pa/
“Then the prominent courtesan Beautiful spoke these verses to the prince:

bu mo 'di ni khyod gsal bgyi snyam nas/ / yun ring snga nas bdag gis bsam bsam ste/ / gzugs mdzes de yang de ring khyod la phul/ / bsod nams legs brgyan yon tan rab dang ldan/ /
tshul khrims blo dang yon tan gzhan gyis kyang / / bu mo dam pa 'di dang 'dra ba ni/ / mi yi 'jig rten gang na'ang ma mchis te/ / 'jig rten kun gyi bud med nang na mchog /
pad+mo'i sbubs nas skyes pas rigs smos su/ / skyon gyi dri mas ma gos 'thad ma lags/ / ma lus skyon gyis ma gos sems dang ldan/ / rtag par khyod kyi spyod tshul mthun par 'gyur/ /
reg na bde la kun nas 'phags pas na/ / 'di yi lus ni shin tu 'jam pa ste/ / bro 'tshal nad pa gang la reg gyur kyang / / de yi mod la bro dang bral bar 'gyur/ /
'di yi lus las spos kyi ngad 'byung ba/ / spos mchog gzhan rnams mngon par zil gyis gnon/ / de yi dri zhim tshor na rnam dag pa'i/ / tshul khrims gnas par mi rnams kun kyang 'gyur/ /
'di yi lus ni gser gyi mdog 'dra ste/ / pad+mo'i mchog ltar rnam par rab tu gsal/ / khros pas bltas na byams pa'i sems ldan par/ / sems can ma lus kun kyang rab tu 'gyur/ /
'di yi tshig snyan yid du 'ong ba ste/ / nyams su bde bas 'gro ba nyan par dga'/ / thos na de rgyus skyon gyi mun pa dang / / mi dge'i sug las bgyid par mos mi 'gyur/ /
'di ni bsam bdag yid la dri med de/ / 'di la kun tu g.yo dang sgyu ma mchis/ / ci smra de dag yid la'ang de bzhin te/ / tshig dbyangs des ni 'gro ba tshim par bgyid/ /
sgyu yis sems can 'drid par mi bgyid de/ / nor gyi don du 'gro ba yongs mi slu/ / yid bsdams khrel gyis 'dzem dang ldan pa ste/ / rgan nam gzhon la'ang rtag tu sri zhu spyod; ;
rigs rgyud gzugs kyis dregs pa ma mchis te/ / 'di ni 'khor gyis dregs pa'ang yongs ma mchis/ / nga rgyal rlom sems yongs dang bral ba ste/ / 'gro ba rnams la rtag tu gus par 'dud/ /

For a long dark time I have wished To give this girl to you; Now this beautiful maiden Of virtue and quality is yours.
There is no girl in the world Equal to her, much less superior; By virtue of her conduct, intellect, and other qualities, She is the best of women in the world.
Born of a lotus, there is no question of her class; She cannot be called impure.
Her mind is free from the taint of all faults; She is capable of sharing your practice.
Her limbs are extremely soft, Conveying the finest pleasures of touch; The sick are instantly cured By her touch.
The pure fragrance of her body Excels all the finest perfumes; All men who smell it Become pure in conduct.
Her body shines like gold, Undefiled like a lotus; Angry and cruel people Become kind when they have seen her.
She speaks kindly, sweetly, pleasantly, A delight to people who hear; When they have heard her, the darkness of evil disperses, And none wants to do anything bad.
Her mind is pure, her heart untainted; There is no guile at all in her. What she says is just what she thinks, And thus she makes people happy.
She does not fool anyone by deceit, Nor does she lead people on for gain; She is modest and discreet, Always respectful to old and young.
She is not fascinated by class Or looks or followers. She has no conceit or arrogance; She is always humble toward all.

de nas rgyal po'i bu gzi brjid kyi bdag po bu mo dga' ba'i 'od kyi dpal shin tu sbyangs pa 'khor dang bcas pa dang / bu mo stong phrag nyi shu dang / 'khor thams cad dang bcas par bza' shing gi ra ba spos kyi myu gu'i rtse mo nas 'od kyi sprin 'byung ba de nas byung ste snying po byang chub chos kyis 'phags pa'i 'od gang na ba der bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa sku nyi ma dam pa gang na ba der bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa sku nyi ma dam pa'i zhal blta ba dang / de la phyag 'tshal ba dang / mchod pa dang / bsnyen bkur ba'i phyir dong ste/ de rta babs sa'i bar du bzhon pas song nas babs te rkang pas bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa sku nyi ma dam pa'i drung du song ngo/ / de nas rgyal po gzhon nu gzi brjid kyi bdag pos rgyang ring po nas bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rab tu bzang ba/ blta na sdug pa/ dbang po zhi ba/ thugs zhi ba; dbang po bsdams pa/ glang po ltar shin tu dul ba/ mtsho ltar shing rnyog pa med la rnam par gsal ba mthong ngo/ /de ltar mthong nas de'i sems mngon par mos par gyur to/ /de ltar sems mngon par mos par gyur nas sangs rgyas mthong ba'i dga' ba dang / mos pa'i shugs chen po rnam par spel te dga' ba dang / mos pa dang / spro ba chen pos yongs su rgyas pa'i sems kyis bcom ldan 'das de la lan brgya stong du mar g.yas phyogs su bskor ba byas nas bu mo dga' ba'i 'od kyi dpal shin tu sbyangs pa la sogs pa 'khor thams cad dang bcas pas bcom ldan 'das de'i zhabs la spyi bos phyag 'tshal te rin po che dam pa'i pad+mo stong phrag lnga brgyas bcom ldan 'das de la mngon par gtor te/ bcom ldan 'das de'i gtsug lag khang lnga brgya nor bu rin po che'i rgyal po spos sna tshogs las byas pa/ rin po che'i rgyal po sna tshogs kyis rab tu brgyan pa lnga brgya brtsigs so/ /gtsug lag khang re re zhing yang nor bu rin po che'i rgyal po stong phrag lnga brgyas rab tu brgyan to/ /

“Then the prince and the maid, with her retinue of twenty thousand girls, left the park and went to the site of enlightenment where the buddha was, to see, pay respects to, make offerings to, and attend the buddha. Going by vehicle as far as the vehicle would go, the prince got off the vehicle and approached the buddha on foot; even at a distance he saw that the buddha was serene, a sight to behold, senses tranquil, mind quiet, senses under control, like a tame elephant, his heart like a clear, still pond. When he saw the buddha, the prince’s mind became settled, and with a clear mind he developed great joy, well-being, and energy that derives from seeing a buddha. With his mind full of great joy, energy, serenity, and rapture, he paid his respects to the buddha, and together with his whole company, including the young woman, covered the buddha with five hundred thousand great jewel lotuses, and made five hundred sanctuaries of jewels for the buddha and adorned each one with five hundred thousand diamonds.

de nas bcom ldan de bzhin de bzhin gshegs pa sku nyi ma dam pas gzhon nu gzi brjid kyi bdag po'i bsam pa thugs su chud nas mdo sde sgo kun tu lta ba'i sgron ma zhes bya ba yang dag par bstan to/ /des de thos nas chos thams cad kyi tshul la ting nge 'dzin gyi sgo rgya mtsho phrag bcu thob par gyur te/ 'di ltar de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi smon lam rgya mtsho yang dag par 'byung ba zhes bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin gyi sgo rab tu thob bo/ /dus gsum snang ba'i snying po zhes bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin gyi sgo rab tu thob bo/ /sangs rgyas thams cad kyi dkyil 'khor mngon du gyur par 'byung ba zhes bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin gyi sgo rab tu thob bo/ /sems can 'byams klas pa thams cad rab tu snang bar bya ba la 'jug pa zhes bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin gyi sgo rab tu thob bo/ / 'jig rten thams cad du 'byung ba'i ye shes kyi snang ba la zhugs pa zhes bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin gyi sgo rab tu thob bo/ /sems can thams cad kyi dbang po rgya mtsho la 'jug pa snang ba'i sgron ma zhes bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin gyi sgo rab tu thob bo/ /'gro ba thams cad yongs su skyob pa'i ye shes kyi sprin ces bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin gyi sgo rab tu thob bo/ /'gro ba thams cad yongs su smin par bya ba dang / gdul ba la mngon du gyur pa'i sgron ma zhes bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin gyi sgo rab tu thob bo/ /de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi chos kyi 'khor lo'i sgra rnams dmigs par byed pa zhes bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin gyi sgo rab tu thob bo/ /kun tu bzang po'i spyod pa'i dkyil 'khor yongs su dag par byed pa'i smon lam gyi sprin ces bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin gyi sgo rab tu thob ste/ ting nge 'dzin gyi sgo bcu po 'di dag la sogs pa chos kyi tshul thams cad la ting nge 'dzin gyi sgo rgya mtsho phrag bcu rab tu thob par gyur to/ /bu mo dga' ba'i 'od kyi dpal shin tu sbyangs pas kyang ye shes thub par dka' ba rgya mtsho'i snying po zhes bya ba'i sems nges par gzhag pa rab tu thob par gyur te/ bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub las kyang phyir mi ldog par gyur to/ /

“Then the buddha, knowing the prince’s strong determination, expounded a scripture called Lamp at the Door of the Universal Eye, upon hearing which the prince attained ten oceans of concentrations absorbed in all principles of the Teaching: he attained ways of concentration such as those called ‘light produced from the oceans of vows of all buddhas,’ ‘path of illumination of past, present, and future,’ ‘going forth into the circle of all buddhas,’ ‘entry into the highest range of awareness of all beings,’ ‘attainment of the scope of knowledge of the causes that produce all worlds,’ ‘lamp illumining the oceans of faculties of all beings,’ ‘cloud of knowledge to save all beings,’ ‘lamp leading to the development and emancipation of all beings,’ ‘communicating the cycles of teaching of all buddhas,’ and ‘multitude of undertakings to purify the practices of universal good.’ Beginning with these, the prince attained ten oceans of concentrations absorbed in all the principles of the Teaching. The young woman attained a meditation called ‘filled with an ocean of invincible knowledge’ and became irreversible in progress toward supreme perfect enlightenment.

de nas rgyal po'i bu gzi brjid kyi bdag pos bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa sku nyi ma dam pa'i zhabs gnyis la spyi bos phyag 'tshal te/ bcom ldan 'das la lan brgya stong du mar g.yas phyogs su bskor ba byas nas bu mo dga' ba'i 'od kyi dpal shin tu sbyangs pa dang / 'khor thams cad dang bcas te bcom ldan 'das de'i spyan snga nas dong ngo/ / de nas rgyal po'i gnas sdong po ri bo'i dpal gang na ba dang / rgyal po yab nor gyi bdag po gang na ba der dong ste drung du phyin nas rgyal po yab nor gyi bdag po'i rkang pa gnyis la spyi bos phyag 'tshal te don 'di brjod do/ /lha'i zhal snga nas mkhyen par mdzad du gsol/ /de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas sku nyi ma dam pa zhes bgyi ba/ mkhyen pa dang zhabs su ldan pa/ bde bar gshegs pa; 'jig rten mkhyen pa/ bla na med pa/ skyes bu 'dul ba'i kha lo sgyur ba/ lha dang mi rnams kyi ston pa sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das 'jig rten du byung ste/ khyod kyi khams 'di de nyid kyi snying po byang chub chos kyi sprin shin tu stug po'i 'od na rnam par spyod de/ mngon par rdzogs par sangs rgyas nas ring po ma lags so/ / de nas rgyal po nor gyi bdag pos gzhon nu gzi brjid kyi bdag po la 'di skad ces smras so/ /gzhon nu khyod la don 'di lha'am/ mi'am/ su zhig gis sbran/ des smras pa/ bdag la bu mo dga' ba'i 'od kyi dpal shin tu sbyangs pas sbran to; ;de nas rgyal po nor gyi bdag pos sangs rgyas byung bar thos nas sangs rgyas skye ba la ni/ gter rab tu thob pa tsam du sems/ sangs rgyas rin po che dang phrad par ni/ dga' bar sems/ de bzhin gshegs pa mthong bas ni/ ngan song gi g.yang sa'i 'jigs pa thams cad kyang rnam par ldog par sems/ nyon mongs pa'i nad chen po rab tu zhi bar bya ba la ni/ sman pa'i rgyal po chen po dang phrad pa tsam du sems/ 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal thams cad las ni/ yongs su 'grel ba yin par sems/ shin tu bde zhing ldan pa la ni; rab tu gzhog par sems/ rab rib med pa'i ye shes kyi snang ba ni/ yang dag par ston par sems/ ma rig pa'i mun pa bsal ba la ni/ sgron ma chen po byung ba tsam du sems/ 'jig rten mgon med pa las ni/ chos kyi tshul gyi mgon dang phrad par sems/ 'jig rten 'dren pa med pa las ni/ thams cad mkhyen pa nyid kyi theg pas 'dren pa skyes par sems shing / sangs rgyas byung bar thos pas mos pa dang / spro ba chen po skyes nas rgyal rigs dang / bram ze dang / ljongs kyi mi dang / yul mi dang / blon po dang / zham ring ba dang / gzhon nu dang / rgyal phran dang / khams kyi bdag po dang / 'khor thams cad kyang kun nas bsdus nas sangs rgyas byung bar sgra snyan pa sgrog pa'i gzhon nu gzi brjid kyi bdag po la rgyal po'i srid de yang chos kyi dga' bar byin no/ /de ltar gzhon nu de rgyal srid la dbang bskur nas srog chags stong phrag bcu dang lhan cig tu bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa sku nyi ma dam pa gang na ba der song ste spyan sngar phyin nas bcom ldan 'das de'i zhabs gnyis la spyi bos phyag 'tshal te/ bcom ldan 'das de la lan brgya stong du mar g.yas phyogs su bskor ba byas nas bcom ldan 'das de'i spyan sngar rang gi 'khor dang bcas te 'khod do/ /

“Then the prince, paying respects to the buddha, left the presence of the buddha with the young woman and the rest of the company and went to his father, the king, in the city. Greeting the king respectfully, he informed him that the buddha Supreme Sun had appeared in the world and was staying in the king’s realm, having recently attained enlightenment. The king then asked the prince who had told him so, and he replied that it had been the young woman Splendor of Delight in Virtuous Conduct.
“Then the king, hearing of the emergence of the buddha, felt that he had gained a great treasure, felt that he had found the rare jewel of Buddha; he considered the sight of a buddha to be the end of the danger of falling into evil ways; he felt he had found a great physician who could heal all afflictions. He thought of the buddha as a liberator from all the sufferings of the mundane whirl, as one who leads to ultimate peace and felicity, as one who reveals the unobscured light of knowledge. He thought of the buddha as the appearance of a great torch dispelling the darkness of ignorance, and felt that he had found a spiritual guide for a world with no guide, thinking of the buddha as a leader to omniscience for the leaderless.
“Hearing of the emergence of the buddha with great joy, the king Lord of Wealth gathered together all the warriors, priests, townspeople, ministers, family priests, princes, and governors, as well as the gatekeepers and courtiers, and abdicated the throne in favor of his son Lord of Glory, who had brought the joyous news of the appearance of the buddha. Then, having crowned the prince as king, he went together with ten thousand people to the buddha, paid his respects, and sat with his retinue before the buddha.

de nas bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa sku nyi ma dam pas rgyal po nor gyi bdag po dang / 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor thams cad la gzigs nas de'i tshe mdzod spu nas 'od zer 'gro ba thams cad kyi sems kyi sgron ma zhes bya ba rab tu bkye'o/ /de phyogs bcu'i 'jig rten gyi khams snang bar byas te/ 'jig rten gyi dbang po thams cad mngon sum du bkod nas sangs rgyas kyi rnam par 'phrul ba bsam gyis mi khyab pa yongs su bstan to/ /sangs rgyas kyis 'dul ba'i sems can rnams kyi bsam pa dang / lhag pa'i bsam pa rnam par sbyangs nas de'i tshe sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs bsam gyis mi khyab pa'i mthus sangs rgyas kyi sku 'jig rten thams cad las mngon par 'phags pa dang / sangs rgyas kyi gsung dbyangs kyi yan lag rgya mtsho thams cad dang ldan pas gzungs kyi sgo chos thams cad la rab rib med pa'i don gyi sgron ma zhes bya ba gzungs kyi sgo sangs rgyas kyi zhing gi rdul shin tu phra ba snyed dang bcas par yang dag par bstan to/ / de nas rgyal po nor gyi bdag pos gzungs kyi sgo de thos nas chos thams cad la chos kyi snang ba chen po skyes par gyur to/ /'khor de'i byang chub sems dpa' 'dzam bu'i gling gi rdul shin tu phra ba snyed kyis kyang chos thams cad la rab rib med pa'i don gyi sgron ma'i gzungs rab tu thob par gyur to/ /khrag khrig drug cus ni/ nye bar len pa med par zag pa las sems rnam par grol lo; ;srog chags stong phrag bcus ni/ chos rnams la chos kyi mig rdul dang bral zhing dri ma med pa rnam par dag par gyur to/ /sems can grangs med pa zhig gis ni/ sngon bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu sems bskyed pa yongs su bskyed do/ /phyogs bcur yang sangs rgyas kyi rnam par 'phrul pa bsam gyis mi khyab pa yongs su bstan pa des sems can gyi khams mtha' dang dbus med pa theg pa gsum gyis dul bar gyur to/ /

“Then the buddha, looking at the king and the whole assembly, emitted a light from the curl of hair between his brows, a light called ‘lamp of the minds of all beings,’ which illumined all worlds in the ten directions, then stopped in front of all the world leaders, displayed inconceivable buddha-projections, clarified the minds of those beings who could be taught by the buddha, and then, by the inconceivable mastery of Buddha, by means of embodiment of Buddha appearing in all worlds, speaking all languages in the voice of Buddha, expounded a medium of mental command called ‘unshaded lamp of meaning of all things,’ which was accompanied by as many media of mental command as atoms in a buddha-land. The king Lord of Wealth, hearing of this medium of mental command, gained an immense spiritual perspective on all things. As many enlightening beings there as atoms in the continent attained the mental command of the unshaded lamp of meaning of all things. Sixty million people, freed from contaminations, were mentally liberated. Ten thousand people became dispassionate and untainted, and their objective vision of things was clarified. An immense number aspired to supreme perfect enlightenment for the first time. Infinitely many beings in the ten directions, by seeing the inconceivable mystic displays projected by the buddha, reached liberation by way of the Three Vehicles.

de nas rgyal po nor gyi bdag po chos kyi snang ba rab tu thob pa de'i yid la 'di snyam ste/ khyim na gnas pas ni/ rnam pa 'di lta bu'i chos kyang khong du chud par mi nus la/ ye shes rnam pa 'di lta bu yang sgrub par mi nus kyi/ bdag ni/ bcom ldan 'das kyi zham ring du rab tu 'byung ngo/ /snyam nas rgyal po nor gyi bdag pos bcom ldan 'das de la 'di skad ces gsol to/ /bcom ldan 'das/ bdag bcom ldan 'das kyi zham ring du rab tu byung zhing bsnyen par rdzogs pa'i dge slong gi tshul la mchis par ci gnang zhes nas bcom ldan 'das des bka' stsal pa/ rgyal po chen po/ de'i dus la bab par shes na rung ngo/ /

“The king Lord of Wealth, having gained great illumination from the Teaching, thought, ‘I cannot apply myself assiduously to such a teaching or accomplish such knowledge while living at home; let me leave home to be with the buddha.’ Then he told the buddha he wanted to receive the precepts from the buddha and leave home to become a mendicant. The buddha assented to this.

de nas rgyal po nor gyi bdag po srog chags stong phrag bcu dang lhan cig tu de bzhin gshegs pa sku nyi ma dam pa'i zham ring du rab tu byung ngo/ /de ltar rab tu byung nas ring po ma lon par gzungs kyi sgo chos thams cad la rab rib med pa'i don gyi sgron ma zhes bya ba 'khor dang bcas par yongs su bsgrubs so/ / bsgoms so/ /shin tu bsgoms so/ /de snyed kyi ting nge 'dzin kyi sgo yang rab tu thob par gyur to/ /byang chub sems dpa'i mngon par shes pa bcu yang rab tu thob bo/ /tha dad pa yang dag par shes pa'i tshul rgya mtsho la'ang yang dag par zhugs par gyur to/ /phyogs bcu'i de bzhin gshegs pa'i drung du 'gro bar thogs pa med pa'i spyod yul zhes bya ba'i lus yongs su dag pa yang rab tu thob ste/ de nas bcom ldan 'das de'i chos kyi 'khor lo yang dag par blangs so/ /yongs su bzung ngo/ /gtam gyi skyes bu yang byas so/ /chos smra ba chen po yang byas so/ /bstan pa yongs su bzung ba yang byas so/ /mngon par shes pa thob pa'i stobs kyis kyang 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad rgyas par bkang ste bsam pa ji lta ba bzhin du sems can rnams la lus yongs su bstan nas sangs rgyas byung ba de rab tu brjod pa dang / sngon gyi de bzhin gshegs pas yongs su bsgrubs pa'i chos nyid mngon par brjod pa dang / sngon gyi sbyor ba phun sum tshogs pa de dag yongs su brjod pa dang / sangs rgyas kyi rnam par 'phrul pa'i mthu de dag yongs su brjod par bya bas bstan pa yongs su bzung pa byas so/ /rgyal po'i sras gzi brjid kyi bdag pos kyang de'i nyin par zla ba nya ste rgyas pa'i tshe rin po che bdun rab tu thob par gyur te/ de khang pa'i steng na bud med kyi tshogs kyis bskor cing 'dug ba'i mdun du 'khor lo rin po che chen po shugs la thogs pa med pa zhes bya brtsibs stong phrag brgya dang ldan pa/ rin po che thams cad kyis brgyan pa/ lha rdzas kyi dzam+bu chu klung gi gser las grub pa/ 'od kun tu 'byung ba/ rnam pa'i mchog thams cad dang ldan pa byung bar gyur to/ /glang po rin po che sna chen po rdo rje rin po che'i ri'i gzi brjid ces bya ba byung bar gyur to/ /rta rin po che ri sngo rlung gi shugs zhes bya ba byung bar gyur to/ /nor bu rin po che chen po nyi ma'i snying po 'od sprin rgyal po zhes bya ba byung bar gyur to/ /bu mo dga' ba'i 'od kyi dpal shin tu sbyangs pa de yang bud med rin po cher byung bar gyur to/ /khyim bdag rin po che nor gyi phung po mang po zhes bya bya ba byung bar gyur to/ /blon po rin po che mig dri ma med pa zhes bya ba yang byung bar gyur te/ de ltar bdun no/ /de de ltar rin po che bdun dang ldan pa'i rgyal po 'khor los bsgyur ba/ gling bzhi la dbang ba/ chos dang ldan pa/ chos kyi rgyal po rnam par rgyal ba dang ldan pa/ yul gyi mthu dang brtson 'grus su ldan par gyur to/ /de la bu dpa' ba rtul phod cing yan lag dam pa'i gzugs dang ldan pa/ pha rol gyi sde rab tu 'joms pa stong yod par gyur te/ des sa chen po 'di skyon med pa dang / dgra med pa dang / gnod pa med pa dang / 'tshe ba med pa dang / skyid pa dang / phun sum tshogs pa dang / bde ba dang / lo legs pa dang / mdangs dga' ba dang / skye bo dang mi mang pos yongs su gang ba yang ri dang rgya mtsho'i mthas klas par chos kyis mngon par rgyal te gnas par byas so/ /

“So then the king and ten thousand of his people left home to follow the buddha. Not long after leaving home, he accomplished the mental command of the unshaded lamp of meaning of all things, along with its subsidiaries, and attained that many concentrations. He also attained ten mystic knowledges of enlightening beings and plunged into infinite oceans of analytic knowledge. He also attained a purity of body called ‘unhindered sphere of action’ in going to see the buddhas of the ten directions. He received the teaching of the buddha, preserved it, and preached it, having become a great spiritual preacher and a practitioner of the teaching. By the power of attainment of mystic knowledge, he pervaded the whole world, appearing to people according to their mentalities, telling them of the emergence of the buddha, illuminating the nature that produces all buddhas, explaining the accomplishment of the past practices of the buddha, praising the miraculous power of the buddha, supporting the buddha’s teaching.
“As for the new king, the son of Lord of Wealth, on that very day, the time of the full moon, he obtained the seven treasures of kingship. As he was sitting in the upper palace surrounded by a group of women, there appeared a great disc called ‘unobstructed momentum,’ adorned with a hundred thousand jewels, made of gold, shining all over, perfectly formed. There also appeared a great elephant named Diamond Mountain Blaze. There also appeared a horse named Swift As the Wind in the Mountains. There also appeared a great jewel called ‘supreme cluster of sunlight.’ There also appeared the young woman Splendor of Delight in Virtuous Conduct, to be his treasure of a wife. There also appeared a treasurer named Mass of Abundant Wealth. There also appeared a military leader, the seventh treasure, called Untainted Eye. Endowed with these seven treasures, he became king, sovereign, ruler of the four continents, just, commander of the law, victorious, with the power and vigor of the people. He also had a full thousand sons, strong and valiant, destroyers of enemy armies. Under his just rule the earth was free from war, free from evil, free from calamity, prosperous, peaceful, pleasant, and well populated.

des 'dzam bu'i gling de'i rgyal po'i gnas stong phrag brgyad cu rtsa bzhi dag tu yang rgyal po'i gnas re rer gtsug lag khang lnga brgya lnga brgya byed du btsud de/ thams cad kyang rnam pa'i mchog thams cad dang ldan pa sha stag go /longs spyod dang yo byad kyi rnam pa thams cad phun sum tshogs pa sha stag go /bza' shing gi ra ba dang / khang pa dang / 'chags dang / dus thams cad du bde bar spyad pa'i nags tshal gyi phreng bas rnam par brgyan pa sha stag go /gtsug lag khang re re zhing yang de bzhin gshegs pa'i mchod rten brtsigs pa ni/ lhun gyi rgya shin tu che bar byas pa ste/ nang rin po che rnam pa mang pos brgyan pa/ rin po che'i rgyal po sna tshogs kyis rnam par spras pa sha stag ste/ rgyal po'i gnas de thams cad du'ang bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa sku nyi ma dam pa 'khor dang bcas pa grong khyer du gshegs par bya ba'i phyir spyan drangs so/ /rgyal po'i gnas de dag kun tu yang de bzhin gshegs pa de la de bzhin gshegs pa'i mchod pa rnam pa thams cad du bsam gyis mi khyab pas mchod de/ sangs rgyas grong khyer du gshegs pa'i cho 'phrul dang / rnam par 'phrul pas sems can tshad med pa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba yongs su bskyed pa'i phyir gshegs su gsol to/ /der yang sems can ma dad pa'i sems dang ldan pa rnams ni/ dad pa thob par gyur to/ /dad pa dang ldan pa'i sems can rnams ni/ sangs rgyas mthong bas dga' ba'i shugs rnam par 'phel bar gyur to/ /dga' ba'i shugs rnam par 'phel ba'i sems can rnams ni/ byang chub kyi bsam pa rnam par dag pa thob par gyur to/ /byang chub kyi bsam pa rnam par dag pa'i sems can rnams ni/ snying rje chen po'i sems bskyed par gyur to/ /sems can la phan par zhugs pa'i sems can rnams ni/ sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad yongs su btsal ba la brtson par gyur to/ /sangs rgyas kyi chos kyi tshul gyi rnam pa la mkhas pa'i sems can rnams ni/ chos thams cad kyi rang bzhin nges par khong du chud par bya ba'i phyir sems mngon par gzhol bar gyur to/ /chos mnyam pa nyid la zhugs pa'i sems can rnams ni/ dus gsum mnyam pa nyid la 'jug pa'i phyir sems mngon par gzhol bar gyur to/ /dus gsum gyi ye shes snang ba thob pa'i sems can rnams ni/ sangs rgyas gcig nas gcig tu brgyud pa rnam par dmigs par bya ba'i don du ye shes snang ba la zhugs par gyur to/ /de bzhin gshegs pa sna tshogs rnam par dmigs par bya ba la zhugs pa'i sems can rnams ni/ 'gro ba thams cad yongs su bsdu ba'i don du sems mngon par gzhol bar gyur to/ /'gro ba thams cad yongs su bsdu ba la brtson pa'i sems can rnams ni/ byang chub sems dpa'i lam rnam par dag par bya ba'i phyir smon lam bskyed par gyur to/ /lam gyi mnyam pa nyid la zhugs pa'i sems can rnams ni/ de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi chos kyi 'khor lo mngon par bsgrub pa'i phyir ye shes snang ba bskyed par gyur to/ /chos rgya mtsho rnam par dbye ba la mngon par mos pa'i sems can rnams ni/ zhing gi dra ba thams cad rang gi lus kyis rgyas par dgang ba'i don du sems mngon par gzhol bar gyur to/ /zhing mnyam pa nyid la zhugs pa'i sems can rnams ni/ sems can thams cad kyi dbang po rgya mtsho yongs su shes par bya ba'i phyir smon lam 'debs par gyur to; ;'gro ba thams cad kyi dbang po dang mos pa ji lta ba bzhin du rnam par dpyad pa la brtson pa'i sems can rnams ni/ thams cad mkhyen pa nyid khong du chud par bya ba'i phyir bsam pa rnam par dag par gyur to/ /sems can rnam pa de lta bu dag gi don rnam pa de lta bu de dag 'grub par 'gyur ba mthong nas rgyal po gzi brjid kyi bdag pos sangs rgyas kyi rnam par 'phrul pa dang / chos 'phrul bsam gyis mi khyab pa bstan pas sems can de dag yongs su smin par bya ba dang / gdul ba'i don du rgyal po'i gnas de dag thams cad du de bzhin gshegs pa sku nyi ma dam pa gshegs su gsol to/ /

“In each of the eighty-four thousand main cities on the continent, he had five hundred sanctuaries built, complete with all the finest features, equipped with all utensils, supplies, and facilities, adorned with gardens, buildings, promenades, and delightful groves. In each sanctuary he also had buddha-memorials built, high and wide, adorned with many arrays of jewels. And he invited the buddha Supreme Sun to all those cities, where he presented the buddha with inconceivable offerings of all kinds. The miracle of the entry of the buddha into the cities fostered virtue in innumerable people, and all those with disturbed minds attained tranquillity, while those with calm minds developed the intense joy of seeing the buddha; those who were full of joy attained purity of will for enlightenment, while those whose will for enlightenment was pure developed great compassion; those of goodwill became involved in the quest for all buddha-teachings, while those who knew the principles of the buddha-teaching set their minds to meditation on the intrinsic nature of all things; those who had realized the equality of things set their minds on realizing the equality of past, present, and future; those who had attained the scope of knowledge of past, present, and future entered into the light of knowledge of the succession of all buddhas, while those who had entered the knowledge of various manifestations of buddhas set their minds on the salvation of all sentient beings; those engaged in the salvation of all beings vowed to complete the path of enlightening beings, while those who had realized the equanimity of the path generated the light of knowledge to bring forth the cycles of teaching of all buddhas; those who were ready for the guidance of the ocean of teachings set their minds on pervading the network of all lands with their own bodies, while those who realized the equality of lands undertook to know the faculties of all sentient beings, and those engaged in consideration of the faculties of all sentient beings in accord with their inclinations purified the determination to reach omniscience. Entering into the fulfillment of such benefits for such people, the king Lord of Glory had the buddha Supreme Sun enter all the cities, to develop and guide those people by the inconceivable vision of the miracles of the Buddha.

rigs kyi bu/ de la ji snyam du sems/ de'i tshe de'i dus na rgyal po'i bu gzhi brjid kyi bdag po zhes bya bar gyur pa de gzhan zhig yin pa snyam du sems na ni/ khyod kyis de ltar mi blta ste/ bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa shAkya thub pa 'di ni/ de'i tshe de'i dus na rgyal po'i bu gzi brjid kyi bdag po zhes bya ba 'khor los bsgyur ba'i rgyal srid la dbang ba/ de bzhin gshegs pa sku nyi ma dam pa la bsnyen bkur byed byed pa de yin no/ /rigs kyi bu; de la ji snyam du sems/ de'i tshe de'i dus na rgyal po nor gyi bdag po gzhon nu gzi brjid kyi bdag po'i yab tu gyur pa de gzhan zhig yin pa snyam du sems na ni/ de ltar mi blta ste; de bzhin gshegs pa rin po che'i me tog gi 'od ces bya ba ni/ de'i tshe de'i dus na rgyal po nor gyi bdag po zhes bya bar gyur pa ste/ da ltar shar phyogs su 'jig rten gyi khams rgya mtsho'i rdul shin tu phra ba snyed kyi 'jig rten gyi khams rgya mtsho'i pha rol gyi 'jig rten gyi khams rgya mtsho chos kyi dbyings nam mkha'i gzugs brnyan gyi sprin ces bya ba na 'jig rten gyi khams kyi rgyud dbu ma dus gsum rab tu snang ba'i rin po che'i rgyal po yongs su 'byung ba'i dbyings zhes bya ba'i 'jig rten gyi khams sangs rgyas kyi 'od kyi dkyil 'khor dpal gyi sgron ma zhes bya ba na snying po byang chub thams cad la dbang ba'i lus rab tu snang ba zhes bya bar bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu mngon par sangs rgyas te; sangs rgyas kyi zhing brjod du med pa'i rdul shin tu phra ba snyed kyi byang chub sems dpa'i 'khor gyis bskor cing chos ston to/ /bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa rin po che'i 'od ces bya ba des sngon byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa mdzad pa'i tshe 'jig rten gyi khams rgya mtsho chos kyi dbyings nam mkha'i gzugs brnyan du snang ba'i sprin yongs su dag par mdzad de/ 'jig rten gyi khams rgya mtsho der de bzhin gshegs pa ji snyed cig byung bar gyur pa dang / 'byung ba dang / 'byung bar 'gyur ba de dag thams cad kyang bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa rin po che'i me tog gi 'od des sngon byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa mdzad pa'i tshe bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu smin phar mdzad pa sha stag go /

“Now, who do you think that prince Lord of Glory was? You should see him as none other than this buddha Shakyamuni, who at that time was a prince named Lord of Glory, who attained kingship, and was on good terms with the buddha Supreme Sun. And who do you think the king Lord of Wealth, father of Lord of Glory, was? You should see him as none other than the buddha Jewel Flower Light, who at that time was a king named Lord of Wealth, who attained supreme perfect enlightenment at an enlightenment site symbolized by reflection of the moon and expounded the Teaching surrounded by as many enlightening beings as atoms in untold buddha-lands in a world called Shining Lamp of the Aura of Buddha in a world system called Family Born of a Diamond Reflecting Past, Present, and Future in the center of an ocean of worlds called Multitude of Reflections in the Space of the Cosmos of Realities, which was to the east past as many oceans of worlds as atoms in a world. Furthermore, that ocean of worlds, Multitude of Reflections in the Space of the Cosmos of Realities was purified by that buddha Jewel Flower Light in the course of his past practice as an enlightening being, and all the past, present, and future buddhas in that ocean of worlds were ripened for supreme perfect enlightenment by that buddha Jewel Flower Light as he carried out the practice of enlightening beings.

rigs kyi bu/ de la ji snyam du sems/ de'i tshe de'i dus na rgyal po'i btsun mo pad+mo dpal gyi snying po 'byung ba zhes bya ba byung ste/ gzhon nu gzi brjid kyi bdag po'i yum du gyur pa/ bud med stong phrag brgyad cu rtsa bzhi'i gtso mor gyur pa de gzhan zhig yin pa snyam du sems na ni/ de ltar mi blta ste/ rigs kyi bu; bcom ldan 'das kyi yum lha mo sgyu ma byang chub sems dpa' skyed skyed pa/ rnam par thar pa kun tu snang zhing sgrib pa med pa la rab tu gnas pa/ sngon de bzhin gshegs pas yongs su bsgrubs pa mngon du gyur pa/ byang chub sems dpa'i skye ba thams cad yongs su bstan pa'i tshul la mkhas pa 'di ni/ de'i tshe de'i dus na rgyal po nor gyi bdag po'i btsun mo dam pa pad+mo dpal gyi snying po 'byung ba zhes bya bar gyur to/ /

“Now then, who do you think was the queen Lotus Born in that time, mother of the prince Lord of Glory, foremost of the eighty-four thousand women? You should see her as none other than Lady Maya, mother of the Blessed Buddha, progenetrix of the enlightening being Vairocana, established in unobstructed liberation of universal light, direct witness to the appearance of the countless multitude of all buddhas, who knows the manner of manifestation of birth of all enlightening beings.

rigs kyi bu/ de la ji snyam du sems/ de'i tshe de'i dus na sbrul tshong ma'i gtso mo blta na sdug pa zhes bya ba byung ba de gzhan zhig yin pa snyam du sems na ni/ de ltar mi blta ste/ shAkya lag na 'khar ba'i chung ma kho mo'i ma mig mdzes zhes bya ba 'di ni/ de'i tshe de'i dus na sbrul tshong ma'i gtso mo blta na sdug pa zhes bya bar gyur to/ / rigs kyi bu/ de la ji snyam du sems/ de'i tshe de'i dus na bu mo dga' ba'i 'od shin tu sbyangs pa zhes bya bar gyur pa de gzhan zhig yin pa snyam du sems na ni/ de ltar mi blta ste/ kho mo ni/ de'i tshe de'i dus na sbrul tshong ma'i bu mo dga' ba'i 'od kyi dpal shin tu sbyangs pa zhes bya bar gyur to/ /

And who do you think was the great courtesan Beautiful? You should see her as Sunetra, wife of Dandapani of the Shakya clan, who is my mother. And who was her daughter, Splendor of Delight in Virtuous Conduct? You should see her as me.
